greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Completely multiplicative with a(prime(n)) = prime(n)^((n+1) mod 2).
comment: To compute a(n) replace odd-indexed primes in the prime factorization of n by 1.
a(p) = p if p is in A031215.
a(p) = 1 if p is in A031368.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: When n = Product_{k>=1} prime(k)^r_k, a(n) = Product_{k>=1} prime(k)^(r_k*((k+1) mod 2)).
a(n) = Product(A027746(n,k): k = 1 .. A001222(n) and A049084(A027746(n,k)) is even). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 06 2015
example: Since 9 = 3^2 and 3 is an even-indexed prime, 3 = prime(2), then a(9) = 3^2 = 9.
Since 35 = 5*7, 5 = prime(3), and 7 = prime(4), we see that a(35) = 1*7 = 7.
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{a, g, pf = FactorInteger@ n}, a = PrimePi[First /@ pf]; g[x_] := If[Or[OddQ@ x, x == 0], 1, Prime@ x]; Times @@ Power @@@ Transpose@ {g /@ a, Last /@ pf}]; Array[f, 120] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 03 2015 *)
Array[Times @@ (FactorInteger[#] /. {p_, e_} /; e > 0 :> (p^Mod[PrimePi@ p + 1, 2])^e) &, 79] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 05 2017 *)
program: [prod([(x[0]^(x[0] in evenIndexPrimes))^x[1] for x in factor(n)]) for n in [1..n]]
(PARI) a(n) = {f = factor(n); for (i=1, #f~, f[i,2] *= (primepi(f[i,1])+1) % 2;); factorback(f);} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Mar 03 2015
results.author: _Tom Edgar_, Mar 03 2015
